Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation2: Before starting a large-scale project tomorrow, the carpenter needs to read and interpret blueprints, drawings, and technical documents
Story: I sat at my workbench, blueprints spread out before me, the lines and measurements blurring together as I tried to focus. Tomorrow was the start of the biggest project I’d ever taken on—a custom kitchen for a client who expected nothing less than perfection. I needed to study every detail tonight, to make sure I didn’t miss a single measurement or instruction. But as I reached for my pencil, my phone buzzed. It was Thursday evening—time for my weekly call with my parents. I could already hear my mother’s gentle voice, asking about my week, wanting to know if I was eating well, if I was happy. They looked forward to these calls, and so did I, usually. But tonight, the weight of the blueprints pressed on me. If I called, I’d lose precious hours of preparation. If I didn’t, I’d disappoint them, maybe even worry them. My thumb hovered over the call button, heart pounding, torn between being a good son and a responsible carpenter, wishing I could be both at once.
